body: FWIW I've [filed a corresponding issue](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=933386) on the `ncurses-term` Debian package.

First of all, thanks for reporting this issue. Alacritty's terminfo file has been added to ncurses relatively recently, which is why it was provided with Alacritty until now. Since ncurses did not make an actual release yet, it was not clearly transparent at which point Debian and Ubuntu would update to it.

> FWIW I've filed a corresponding issue on the ncurses-term Debian package.

Please note for future reference, that it's probably a better idea to report things in one place first before creating multiple issues. This is not something where Debian can do much, so it just generates a bit of unnecessary noise and work upstream. Checking here first should be a good way to keep that down, I can usually respond to issues within a day.

> Now that I think about it, perhaps this should be considered a bug on ncurses-term's part... Or perhaps ncurses-term could be listed as a dependency of alacritty's generated .deb package (provided the contents of the terminfo file are never expected to change)?

This is not a bug of ncurses-term. Alacritty's .deb is not an official Debian package, but only built by Alacritty's CI. So there's no way for Debian maintainers to know anything about it. So this is something where Alacritty's .deb file needs to be adjusted.

Adding ncurses-term as a dependency without packaging the terminfo files in the .deb file is likely a good idea.

As maintainer of ncurses in Debian, I agree.

> Adding ncurses-term as a dependency without packaging the terminfo files in the .deb file is likely a good idea.

The alacritty terminfo entries have only been added a few days ago in Debian's and Ubuntu's development versions, it will take a while until they reach the wide public in stable releases (Ubuntu 20.04 and Debian 11). So maybe Alacritty's .deb could continue to include these files, but move them under /lib/terminfo where they do not clash with ncurses-term?

BTW, the terminfo installation in Alacritty's .deb is broken: it includes the **source** file as /usr/share/terminfo/a/alacritty rather than feeding it to tic and installing the compiled files. As a result, TERM is set to xterm-256color.

> BTW, the terminfo installation in Alacritty's .deb is broken: it includes the source file as /usr/share/terminfo/a/alacritty rather than feeding it to tic and installing the compiled files. As a result, TERM is set to xterm-256color.

I thought the same thing looking at the configuration right now, though I don't have a Debian system to confirm it. I'm surprised this has slipped through, since it has been there for a long time, though at least now we know.

> The alacritty terminfo entries have only been added a few days ago in Debian's and Ubuntu's development versions, it will take a while until they reach the wide public in stable releases (Ubuntu 20.04 and Debian 11). So maybe Alacritty's .deb could continue to include these files, but move them under /lib/terminfo where they do not clash with ncurses-term?

Especially since Debian 10 has been released just recently and even 20.04 is still a bit of time away, this is a very good point. Though as mentioned previously I'd have to setup a Debian VM to test what the best solution would be. On Arch /lib/terminfo is symlinked to /usr/share/terminfo, so it wouldn't work, however if this is not the case on Debian and it's still loaded, that would be a great option.

I think we can just execute `tic` in the `extra/linux/debian/positinst` script, however we'd still have to first copy it somewhere.

> > The alacritty terminfo entries have only been added a few days ago in Debian's and Ubuntu's development versions, it will take a while until they reach the wide public in stable releases (Ubuntu 20.04 and Debian 11). So maybe Alacritty's .deb could continue to include these files, but move them under /lib/terminfo where they do not clash with ncurses-term?

> Especially since Debian 10 has been released just recently and even 20.04 is still a bit of time away, this is a very good point. Though as mentioned previously I'd have to setup a Debian VM to test what the best solution would be. On Arch /lib/terminfo is symlinked to /usr/share/terminfo, so it wouldn't work, however if this is not the case on Debian and it's still loaded, that would be a great option.

On Debian and derivatives, /lib/terminfo will most likely never be a symlink to /usr/share/terminfo (unless the local admin has made one, and then they keep the pieces). 

> I think we can just execute `tic` in the `extra/linux/debian/positinst` script, however we'd still have to first copy it somewhere.

I had thought of running tic at package build time, but that does not seem possible with cargo-deb.  So you would probably have to include alacritty.info in the .deb, say in /usr/share/alacritty, and then use maintainerscripts like these (untested):

postinst:
```
#!/bin/sh
set -e
tic -x -o /lib/terminfo /usr/share/alacritty/alacritty.info
```
prerm:
```
#!/bin/sh
set -e
rm -f /lib/terminfo/alacritty /lib/terminfo/alacritty+common /lib/terminfo/alacritty-direct
```

> I had thought of running tic at package build time, but that does not seem possible with cargo-deb. So you would probably have to include alacritty.info in the .deb, say in /usr/share/alacritty, and then use maintainerscripts like these (untested)

This was my thought as well. Without having the ability to generate files in cargo-deb during the installation based on files in the repository, that seems to be the best choice.
I have taken the time to write a patch that should do the trick. However I will not send a pull request, since I have no way to test it.

@zwenna I just built from your commit on debian sid (unstable), and it seems to have fixed the bug. `apt upgrade` was failing on `ncurses-term (6.1+20190713-1)` but it's now happily installed side-by-side with your version of alacritty.
Nice!

@laurentS Can you check if the Alacritty terminfo is still provided in lib? And optimally backing up the ncurses-term terminfo, removing the Alacritty from it and then checking if `TERM=alacritty` still works?


`/lib/terminfo/a/` doesn't contain any alacritty file, nor do the other folders listed above. Also `/lib` is a symlink to `/usr/lib` in case it's useful.

About `TERM=alacritty`, it works after installing the `.deb` (assuming you mean `$ env | grep TERM`, if not, please let me know what to check exactly). And it still seems to work even after I remove the terminfo file from `/usr/share/terminfo/a/` so I suspect I might be doing something wrong.

@zwenna on my system, `tic` compiles the terminfo files to `/lib/terminfo/a/alacritty*` when I run `sudo tic -x -o /lib/terminfo /usr/share/alacritty/alacritty.info` so the `prerm` script probably won't remove them properly.

Hope the above helps. Please let me know if I can test anything else.

Chiming in with input for Debian testing.

> I have taken the time to write a patch that should do the trick. However I will not send a pull request, since I have no way to test it.

Confirming that it works. Upgraded alacritty to @zwenna's `terminfo` branch, then upgraded `ncurses-term` with no problems.

> Can you check if the Alacritty terminfo is still provided in lib?

Confirming @laurentS' findings on Debian testing:

* `/lib` is symlinked to `/usr/lib`
* no alacritty terminfo file can be found anywhere under `/lib`.

(FWIW `/lib` is **not** symlinked to `/usr/lib` on Raspbian.)

> ...checking if `TERM=alacritty` still works?

* works with the terminfo file provided by `ncurses-term`
* doesn't work with the alacritty terminfo file removed.
* oddly, did _not_ work with the terminfo file provided by the current version of alacritty.

  Before upgrading `ncurses-term`, I would get the following in an alacritty window:

  ```
  $ echo $TERM
  xterm-256color
  $ file /usr/share/terminfo/a/alacritty
  /usr/share/terminfo/a/alacritty: ASCII text
  $ export TERM=alacritty
  $ infocmp
  infocmp: couldn't open terminfo file /usr/share/terminfo/a/alacritty
  ```

  I'm beginning to get the sense I should have compiled the terminfo file with `tic`.

FWIW I'd been inadvertently using alacritty with `TERM=xterm-256color` this whole time, and had no idea anything was wrong.

> `/lib/terminfo/a/` doesn't contain any alacritty file, nor do the other folders listed above. Also `/lib` is a symlink to `/usr/lib` in case it's useful.

Should not matter if /lib is a symlink to /usr/lib or a directory.

> About `TERM=alacritty`, it works after installing the `.deb` (assuming you mean `$ env | grep TERM`, if not, please let me know what to check exactly). And it still seems to work even after I remove the terminfo file from `/usr/share/terminfo/a/` so I suspect I might be doing something wrong.

The .deb installs the terminfo files under /lib/terminfo, so removing files from /usr/share/terminfo has no effect, that is to be expected.

> @zwenna on my system, `tic` compiles the terminfo files to `/lib/terminfo/a/alacritty*` when I run `sudo tic -x -o /lib/terminfo /usr/share/alacritty/alacritty.info` so the `prerm` script probably won't remove them properly.

Thanks, fixed that and force-pushed my branch.  There should be the following files in /lib/terminfo/a:

After installing the .deb:

alacritty
alacritty+common
alacritty-direct
ansi

Before installing and after removing it:

ansi
